The moon on Karwa Chauth often rises late, a result of its natural orbit, Earth's position, and cosmic harmony. This delay aligns with the celestial rhythm, creating a beautiful tradition.
Karwa Chauth is observed on the fourth day (Chaturthi) of the moon's waning phase (Krishna Paksha). As it's just four days after the full moon, the moon rises later in the evening.
The moon rises about 50 minutes later daily, so by the fourth waning day, moonrise shifts well past the timing of the full moon.
The exact time the moon rises depends on your latitude and longitude, which is why moonrise varies between different cities.
